Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

questions.text: A 30-week primigravida c/o reduced vision at night. She has been avoiding papaya, mango, and other fruits throughout her pregnancy as she thinks they could be abortifacients. It is the primary duty of which of the following workers to provide counselling and information to the patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) AWW

 

The described scenario involves a pregnant woman with a misconception about the consumption of certain fruits during pregnancy and a symptom of night blindness, which could indicate a deficiency in Vitamin A. The Anganwadi Worker (AWW) is primarily responsible for providing health and nutrition education and counselling to mothers, which includes information about proper dietary practices during pregnancy. AWWs are trained to address specific local challenges that prevent healthy behaviors, such as cultural practices, myths, local food availability, and dietary practices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife): ANMs primarily focus on providing basic medical care, immunizations, and assisting with childbirth and antenatal care. While they do offer some nutritional advice, the specific role of counselling about dietary misconceptions primarily falls under the AWW.

 

Option C. Trained birth attendant: Trained birth attendants are primarily involved in assisting with childbirth and ensuring safe delivery practices. Their role does not typically include extensive nutritional counselling.

 

Option D. ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist): ASHAs work to promote community health and link the community with health services. They play a supportive role in health education, but detailed nutritional counselling is more specifically the responsibility of the AWW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is the duty of the Anganwadi Worker (AWW) to provide health and nutrition education and counselling to pregnant women, addressing misconceptions about diet and ensuring they receive proper nutritional guidance. Their training includes addressing local challenges and cultural practices to promote healthy behaviors.

questions.text: All of the following are types of polysaccharide vaccines except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hepatitis B

 

Hepatitis B is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant type of subunit vaccine, which means it is made using genetic engineering techniques to produce the surface antigens of the Hepatitis B virus

 

Other Options:

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are designed to elicit an immune response specifically against the polysaccharides found on the surface of certain bacterial capsules. These vaccines include:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae B (Hib) vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

These vaccines may also be available as glycoconjugate vaccines, which are designed to improve immunogenicity, especially in younger populations. However, the vaccine for Salmonella Typhimurium (Typhim VI) is available only in a polysaccharide form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B is a recombinant subunit vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine. Polysaccharide vaccines include those for pneumococcus, meningococcus, and Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Note - Polysaccharide vaccines work by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies specifically against the polysaccharide components of the bacterial capsule. These polysaccharides are unique to particular strains or serotypes of bacteria, making the vaccine effective in targeting those specific types.

 

Limitations of Polysaccharide vaccines: serotype-specific and do not facilitate herd immunity due to their lack of a robust T-cell response.

Based on the guidelines for biomedical waste management, which type of waste should be correctly disposed of in the following mentioned bag? [AIIMS MAY 2017]

choices.text: Testing all the dogs for rabies
Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs
Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance

questions.text: While numerous animals play a role in the transmission of rabies, dogs stand out as the most common ones. Moreover, the impact of this disease is often more in children. Given this understanding, what approach would be both economically efficient and rational to reduce the occurrence of rabies? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs

 

Since dogs are the primary source of infection, the most cost-effective (and logical) strategy would be Elimination of stray dogs and taking a step towards mass immunization. This approach directly addresses the primary source of infection and helps break the transmission cycle of the rabies virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testing all the dogs for rabies: Not economically efficient due to the large number of dogs and the high cost of testing. It also does not prevent the spread of the disease.

 

Option C. Strengthening laboratory facilities: While important for diagnosis and monitoring, this does not address the primary prevention of rabies through vaccination and control of the dog population.

 

Option D. Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance: Surveillance is crucial but does not directly prevent rabies transmission. It is more of a reactive approach rather than a proactive prevention strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reducing the stray dog population and vaccinating all dogs is the most economically efficient and rational approach to reduce the occurrence of rabies. This strategy directly targets the primary source of infection and helps prevent the spread of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrectly matched? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Diagnostic Study - CONSORT

 

  • The reporting standards employed for presenting the outcomes of Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) are known as CONSORT, which stands for Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials.
  • CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) is intended for reporting the outcomes of randomized controlled trials (RCTs), not diagnostic studies.
  • The correct reporting guidelines for diagnostic studies are STARD (Standards for Reporting of Diagnostic Accuracy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observational study – MOOSE: MOOSE is Meta-analyses Of Observational Studies in Epidemiology

 

Option B. Systematic review – PRISMA: The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement (2009) helps systematic reviewers transparently report why the review was done, what the authors did, and what they found.

 

Option D. Case report – CARE: The CARE guidelines (for CAse REports) were developed by an international group of experts to support an increase in the accuracy, transparency, and usefulness of case reports.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note - More reporting guidelines can be found on Equator network

choices.text: Case Fatality Rate
Age-Specific Mortality Rate
Crude Death Rate
Standardized Age Mortality Ratio

questions.text: A 50-year-old epidemiologist is reviewing mortality data from different countries to compare overall health outcomes. He notices significant variations in crude death rates between nations, which seem misleading due to the differences in the structures of their populations. To make a meaningful comparison, he decides to use a statistical measure that adjusts the death rates of each country. What is the term used to describe this adjustment of death rates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Standardized Age Mortality Ratio

 

Explanation:

 

The Standardized Age Mortality Ratio (SAMR) represents the death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution. This adjustment process allows for a fair comparison of mortality rates between populations with different age structures by removing the confounding effects of varying age distributions. The SAMR is calculated by applying the age-specific mortality rates of a population to a standard age distribution, which helps in understanding the actual mortality risk without the influence of demographic differences.

 

Key Points on Standardization:

 

Age standardization is critical when comparing death rates across populations with differing age compositions.

 

It involves either direct or indirect methods using a standard population's age distribution.

 

Standardization eliminates biases caused by variations in age structures between populations, making comparisons valid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case Fatality Rate
This rate measures the proportion of deaths from a specific condition among those diagnosed, without adjusting for age distribution across different populations.

 

Option B. Age-Specific Mortality Rate
This rate reflects deaths within specific age groups but does not account for the overall population's age structure, limiting comparability.

 

Option C. Crude Death Rate
This rate measures the total deaths in a population without adjusting for age structure, making it less accurate for comparisons between populations with different age distributions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Standardized Age Mortality Ratio adjusts the death rate of a population to a standard age distribution, facilitating accurate comparisons between populations. This adjustment is crucial for assessing true mortality risk and understanding health outcomes across different regions or demographic groups without the confounding effect of varying age structures.

questions.text: A 60-year-old farmer reports symptoms of fever, body pain, and a cough. A physical examination reveals a black lesion as depicted in the accompanying image. Laboratory tests confirm the presence of IgM antibodies indicative of Scrub Typhus infection. What treatment approach would be most advisable in this case? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Doxycycline alone

 

Explanation:

 

  • This black lesion is Eschar and this is the acute case of Scrub Typhus.
  • Causative organism - Rickettsia tsutsugamushi; Vector - Mite
  • The preferred approach depends on the severity of the condition and individual patient considerations.

 

Option A. Doxycycline Alone:

 

  1. Use: This is the first-line treatment for Scrub Typhus.
  2. Mechanism: Doxycycline works by inhibiting protein synthesis in bacteria, effectively controlling the infection.
  3. Why Prefer: It's highly effective and typically well-tolerated, making it suitable for most cases unless contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Doxycycline + Azithromycin: Used when there is co-infection with other pathogens that azithromycin can cover or when doxycycline alone isn't adequately effective.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone + Doxycycline: This combination might be used in more severe cases or when the patient has complications that might benefit from a broader antibiotic coverage.

 

Option D. Ceftriaxone Alone: While effective against many types of bacteria, it's not the targeted treatment for Scrub Typhus and generally not recommended unless other options are contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Doxycycline alone is usually sufficient and most advisable for uncomplicated Scrub Typhus. 
  • Combination therapies may be considered in specific clinical scenarios where co-infections or severe presentations are evident.

choices.text: Maternal Deaths per 10,000 women in reproductive age group
Maternal Deaths per 100,000 women in reproductive age group

questions.text: Dr. Aishwarya, a public health official, is discussing the maternal health situation in a rural district of Uttar Pradesh at a Panchayat meeting. She emphasizes the importance of understanding the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for her district. Which definition best describes the MMR? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Maternal Deaths per 100,000 live births 

 

  • MMR is Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births.
  • Maternal Mortality rate (MMR): Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births, where a ‘maternal death’ is defined as ‘death of a woman while pregnant or during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes’.
  • MMR is a ratio (Maternal mortality rate is a misnomer; MMR is not a rate)

 

 

Additional Information

 

  • MMR World: 216 per 100,000 live births; Causes of MMR (globally):
    • Hemorrhage (25%)
    • Indirect causes (20%)
    • Infection (15%)
    • Unsafe abortion (13%)
    • Eclampsia (12%)
    • Obstructed labour (8%)
  • MMR India: 97 per 100,000 live births [2023]; Causes of MMR (India) [SRS 2023]:
    • Hemorrhage (38%)
    • Other conditions (34%)
    • Sepsis (11%)
    • Abortion (8%)
    • Obstructed labour (5%)
    • Hypertensive disorders (5%)
  • Maternal mortality rate (MMRate): Dividing the average annual number of maternal deaths in a population by the average number of women of reproductive age (typically those aged 15 to 49 years) who are alive during the observation period. 

 

MMRate reflects not only the risk of maternal death per pregnancy or per birth, but also the level of fertility in a population

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MMR is a crucial indicator of maternal health in a population, reflecting the risk of maternal death associated with childbirth and its management.
  • It is typically expressed per 100,000 live births to provide a clear picture of maternal health risks and the effectiveness of health interventions aimed at reducing these risks in specific areas or populations.

choices.text: It can be reduced by matching
It is associated individually with both cause and effect
It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
It is associated with the exposure of the study

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding a confounding factor? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) It is distributed equally in both study and control groups

 

  • Confounding factor: Any factor associated with both exposure and outcome, and has an independent effect in causation of outcome is a confounder.
  • It is found unequally distributed between the study and control groups

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can be reduced by matching:  Matching is a technique used in study design to control for confounding by ensuring that study groups are comparable with respect to potential confounders.

 

Option C. It is distributed equally in both study and control groups:  This statement is incorrect. A confounding factor is typically unequally distributed between the study and control groups. If it were equally distributed, it would not confound the results.

 

Option D. It is associated with the exposure of the study:  A confounder is associated with the exposure and can influence the observed effect of the exposure on the outcome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Confounding can be removed by

 

1. Matching → MC used /simplest method

2. Randomization → 2nd Best Method

3. Restriction

4. Stratification

5. Statistical Modelling / Multivariate analysis (MVA)

6. Stratified Randomization → Overall Best Method

questions.text:
A study aimed to assess the effectiveness of CA-125 as a screening marker for ovarian cancer. Histopathological confirmation was used to determine the true presence of ovarian cancer. The study found that:

  • 60 out of 100 women with a positive CA-125 test actually had ovarian cancer.
  • 20 out of 100 women with a negative CA-125 test had ovarian cancer.

Calculate the negative predictive value (NPV) of the CA-125 test based on these results. (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. 80/100

 

Explanation:

 

Negative Predictive Value (NPV) answers the question: "If the test is negative, what is the probability that the person truly does NOT have the disease?"

It is calculated as:

 

  • NPV = True Negatives / (True Negatives + False Negatives)

 

From the given data, we can construct the following 2x2 table:

 

 

Export to Sheets

 

  • True Negatives (TN): Number of people who tested negative and truly do not have the disease = 80
  • False Negatives (FN): Number of people who tested negative but actually have the disease = 20

 

NPV = 80 / (80 + 20) = 80/100

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. 20/100: This represents the False Negative rate (FN / (FN + TN))
  • Option B. 40/100: This is not directly related to any of the standard metrics for evaluating a diagnostic test
  • Option C. 60/100: This represents the True Positive rate or Sensitivity (TP / (TP + FN))

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The negative predictive value (NPV) is the probability that a person with a negative test result truly does not have the disease.
  • NPV is calculated as True Negatives / (True Negatives + False Negatives)

questions.text:
A woman presents to a clinic with her son, Ram, who has developed symptoms consistent with Measles, including fever and rash. She mentions that Ram's brother, Shyam, exhibited similar symptoms a few days earlier. Which of the following statements regarding the situation are accurate? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

  1. Ram is the index case
  2. Shyam is primary case
  3. Ram got infected from Shyam
  4. If mother had reported when Shyam got infection, Ram could have been vaccinated
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) All are correct

 

Index case: The first case that comes to the notice of the investigator. In this situation, Ram is the index case as he is the one presented to the clinic first.

 

Primary case: The first case of a disease in a population. Shyam, who exhibited symptoms a few days earlier, is the primary case.

 

Transmission: Given the incubation period of measles (7 to 18 days), it is likely that Ram got infected from Shyam, who was in an infectious state.

 

Post-exposure prophylaxis: If the mother had reported Shyam's infection, Ram could have received post-exposure prophylaxis. This can be in the form of a measles vaccine within 72 hours of exposure or immunoglobulin up to 6 days post-exposure.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Index case → First case that comes to the notice of investigator.
  • Primary case → First case of a disease in a population.
  • Incubation period of measles infection is 7 to 18 days
  • Vaccine can be given within 72 hours of post-exposure and immunoglobulin can be given up to 6 days’ post-exposure.

questions.text: In the infectious disease ward, you notice a multi-drug therapy packet placed neatly on a patient's bedside table. Based on the drug composition, which of the following diseases do you think the packet is intended to treat? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Leprosy

 

The given image shows the adult blister packet used in the treatment of leprosy.

 

 

 

Additional Information

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB: TB treatment involves a different combination of drugs, typically including isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.

 

Option C. Vaginal discharge: Treatment for vaginal discharge depends on the specific cause, such as bacterial, fungal, or protozoal infection, and usually involves single-agent therapy.

 

Option D. Gonorrhea: Gonorrhea treatment generally involves antibiotics like ceftriaxone and azithromycin, not a multi-drug blister packet.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Based on the depiction in the accompanying image, which model of disease causation is being illustrated? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Sufficient component cause model 

 

  • The model of disease causation depicted is a sufficient component cause model.
  • It was developed by Rothman based on the idea that an outcome can only happen when a sufficient cause is present.
  • A disease can have multiple sufficient causes. But each sufficient cause can consist of a pie chart of component causes, a causal pie.
  • One component cause can be a part of more than one sufficient cause.
  • A component cause can be considered necessary if it is a part of a disease's sufficient causes.
  • In the given model, each pie chart represents a sufficient cause made of component causes.
  • Since B is present in all the charts, it can be considered a necessary cause. All the others are contributing causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epidemiological triad: An epidemiological triad depicts the interrelationship between the causative agent, the host, and the environment. All of them contribute to disease development. The aim of an epidemiological triad is to identify how to break this relationship and prevent the outbreak of the disease.

 

Option C. PERT model: PERT is used for network analysis. It is a type of quantitative management technique that helps in detailed planning and comprehensive supervision.

 

 

Option D. Web of causation model: The web of causation considers all the predisposing factors and their complex interrelationship with each other. This model is ideally suited to study chronic disease. The web of causation does not imply that the disease is controlled only when all the multiple chains of causation are removed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sufficient component cause model illustrates how multiple factors contribute to disease causation, with some factors being necessary components in multiple causal pathways.

questions.text: Which one of the provided thermometers is employed for measuring low air velocity as opposed to the cooling potency of the air? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Kata thermometer 

 

Kata thermometer is used to measure low air velocity rather than the cooling power of the air. It works by measuring the temperature difference between two thin wires heated to different temperatures in a moving air stream. The faster the air moves, the greater the temperature difference between the two wires, allowing the Kata thermometer to measure air velocity.

 

Other Options

Option B. Globe Thermometer: Measures mean radiant temperature, which is the average temperature of all the surfaces surrounding a particular point. This is useful in assessing thermal comfort in environments.

 

Option C. Wet Globe Thermometer: Used to measure heat stress by taking into account temperature, humidity, wind speed, and solar radiation. It is commonly used in the Wet Bulb Globe Temperature (WBGT) index.

Option D. Dial Thermometer: Measures air temperature using a dial indicator. It is a general-purpose thermometer and not specifically designed for measuring air velocity.


Educational Objective:

choices.text: In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive
Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease
Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease
Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease

questions.text: Among the following options, which statement accurately represents the relationship between prevalence of a disease and characteristics of a diagnostic test? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease

 

  • The accuracy of a screening test's positive predictive value (PP) relies on the disease's prevalence.
  • PPV, which stands for positive predictive value, signifies the chance that a patient showing a positive test outcome has indeed acquired the disease.
  • In other words, it represents the probability that an individual with a positive test result genuinely possesses the disease.

 

PPV of a screening test depends on:

 

  • Sensitivity
  • Specificity
  • Prevalence of disease in the population

 

PPV of a screening test is directly proportional to the prevalence of disease in the population

 

  • PPV α Prevalence of disease
  • As the prevalence of a disease increases in a population, PPV increases for the screening test

 

Sensitivity and Specificity are independent of the prevalence the of disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive: This is misleading because in populations with a low prevalence, a positive result from even a highly sensitive test could still be a false positive due to the low likelihood of the disease.

 

Option B. Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease and Option D. Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease Sensitivity and specificity are intrinsic characteristics of a test that are determined by comparing the test results against a gold standard and are independent of disease prevalence in the population being tested. They remain constant regardless of how common or rare the disease is within that group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The positive predictive value (PPV) of a diagnostic test is significantly influenced by the prevalence of the disease within the population.
  • PPV indicates the probability that individuals who test positive actually have the disease.
