questions.text: You are a nutritionist giving a lecture about milk pasteurization and its quality assurance tests. A curious student inquires about the various tests to validate the efficacy of pasteurization. You begin to list them, but highlight one that is not directly related to the pasteurization process. Which of the following tests does not directly evaluate the efficiency of milk pasteurization? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) lodine test 

 

  • Given tests are associated with the milk pasteurization process except for the iodine test.
  • This test is conducted to examine the potential adulteration of milk with starch or cereal flour.
  • Iodine test - The presence of addition of starch in milk can be detected using an iodine test.
  • When two or three drops of iodine solution is added to milk taken in a test tube, the solution turns dark blue.
  • This shows the presence of starch mixed with the milk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphatase Test: Used to check for the presence of the enzyme phosphatase, which should be inactivated by proper pasteurization. This ensures that the milk has been heated sufficiently.

 

Option C. Standard Plate Count: Measures the total bacterial count to ensure it meets the standards for pasteurized milk. A lower count indicates effective pasteurization.

 

Option D. Methylene Blue Reduction Test: Measures the time it takes for methylene blue to lose its color, which correlates with bacterial activity; high counts indicate inadequate pasteurization. This test helps verify the reduction of microbial load.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PASTEURIZATION TESTS:

 

  1. Phosphatase Test: Widely used test
  2. Standard Plate Count: Standard is coliforms be absent in 1 ml of milk
  3. Methylene blue reduction test: Enforced limit is 30,000 bacterial count per ml of pasteurized milk

questions.text: A study on 100 urban women evaluates potential risk factors for breast cancer using odds ratios (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI). An OR > 1 with a CI not including 1 suggests a significant association. How many risk factors show a statistically significant association with breast cancer? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 3

 

In the above statistical group, the odds ratio of early menarche, BRCA mutation, and obesity show positive association and are statistically significant.

 

A high socioeconomic status does not pose a risk factor. Despite observing a positive correlation, the statistical significance is absent. Any correlation with a 95% confidence interval with the value of 1.0 is deemed as statistically insignificant. A value of 1.0 within this range implies that both factors can coexist without one being the cause of the other.

Odds ratio (OR) is the key parameter in case-control studies to assess the strength of association between the exposure and outcome. The interpretation of the odds ratio can be done as below:

 

  • OR > 1 indicates a positive association.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association.
  • OR < 1 indicates a negative (protective) association.

 

Interpretation of the individual factors given in the question:

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

There are three factors (early menarche, BRCA mutation, obesity), that have statistically significant associations with breast cancer according to the odds ratios and their 95% confidence intervals provided.

questions.text: A researcher is comparing the means of three different groups with non-normally distributed data and small sample sizes. Which of the following tests is best suited for analyzing this non-parametric data? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Friedman test

 

  • Friedman test is a non-parametric statistical test used for detecting differences in treatments across multiple test attempts.
  • It is the equivalent of a one-way ANOVA with repeated measures but for non-parametric data.
  • Since the data in this scenario is not normally distributed, and the groups are related, the Friedman test is the appropriate choice.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Student t-test: Student t-test is used for comparing the means of two groups. However, it assumes that the data is normally distributed. 

 

Option C. ANOVA: ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used for comparing the means of three or more independent groups. 

 

Option D. Pearson: Pearson correlation is used for measuring the strength of a linear association between two quantitative variables. It is not a test for comparing means and also assumes a normal distribution of the data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Choose the Friedman test when you need to compare the means of three or more related groups, and the data is not normally distributed, ensuring accurate and reliable statistical analysis in non-parametric settings.

questions.text: As per the Factories Act of 1948, what is the maximum permissible weekly working hours, inclusive of overtime? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 60 hours

 

The Factories Act of 1948 permits a maximum of 48 hours of regular work per week, which can be extended up to 60 hours per week with standard overtime.

 

Factories Act – established in 1948:

 

  • Established to include all the factories except Defence, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
  • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
  • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
  • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
  • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48 hours per week or less than 9 hours per day.
  • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maximum work hours per week is 48 hours. With overtime one can extend it upto 60 hours.

choices.text: Give DMPA with 7 days of barrier

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with no significant medical history, who has been using depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) for contraception, presents to the clinic after missing her scheduled injection by 14 days. She denies any sexual activity since her last injection. Her last menstrual period was 10 weeks ago, and she has no signs of pregnancy. What is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient regarding contraception? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Give DMPA

 

Explanation:

 

  • As per the ministry of health and family welfare guidelines, ideally Inj DMPA (Antara) should be administered 3 monthly as shown in the table below:

 

Follow up of clients (coming on scheduled date for next injection i.e after 3 months

 

 

  • Defaulter: A defaulter is a client who does not return for the next injection on the scheduled date; but comes for it within the grace period i.e. 2 weeks earlier and upto 4 weeks later from the scheduled date).

 

 

Drop out: A dropout is a MPAclient who comes for the next injection after the grace period of 4 weeks is over and more than 4 months have passed since she took her last injection

 

 

In the scenario mentioned above, the patient is a DEFAULTER and hence the Inj should be administered as she falls within the grace period

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. UPT before DMPA: This would be appropriate if the patient was a drop-out, i.e. if she had presented > 4 weeks of the date that she had to come on. 

 

Option C. Give DMPA with 7 days of barrier: This approach would be recommended if the injection was delayed beyond 4 weeks. 

 

Option D. Wait till next period: This unnecessarily delays contraceptive protection and is not recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient misses her scheduled DMPA injection by up to 30 days, the most appropriate recommendation is to administer DMPA directly without pregnancy testing. 

  • This is because Inj DMPA is known to cause a delayed return to fertlity. 

  • This ensures continuous contraceptive protection while following evidence-based guidelines that balance safety with practical clinical considerations.

choices.text: Differential mRNA processing

questions.text: Affinity maturation of antibodies is because of? ((INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Somatic hypermutation

 

Option A. Somatic hypermutation: Affinity maturation primarily occurs in the germinal centers of secondary lymphoid organs, such as lymph nodes and spleen. The cause of affinity maturation is Somatic hypermutation.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Differential mRNA Processing: This process involves chemical modification of mRNA during mRNA processing. While it is important for generating diversity in certain proteins, it is not directly related to affinity maturation of antibodies.

 

Option C. CD40: CD40 is a co-stimulatory molecule involved in B cell activation. It plays a role in the interaction between B cells and T cells. While it is important for various aspects of immune response, it is not the primary cause of affinity maturation.

 

Option D. Gene Rearrangements: Gene rearrangements, specifically V(D)J recombination, occur during the early development of B cells. This process creates diversity in the variable regions of antibody genes. While important for generating initial antibody diversity, it is not the primary cause of affinity maturation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Affinity maturation is a process by which antibodies undergo modifications to enhance their binding affinity for a specific antigen over time. This is crucial for the adaptive immune system to generate more effective and specific immune responses.

 

Somatic Hypermutation (SHM):

Definition: Somatic hypermutation is a process that introduces point mutations into the variable regions of immunoglobulin genes in B cells.

 

Location: It occurs in the germinal centers of secondary lymphoid organs during the B cell response to an antigen.

 

Purpose: The primary goal of somatic hypermutation is to introduce random mutations in the variable regions of the immunoglobulin genes, leading to a diverse set of antibodies with different binding affinities.

 

Outcome: B cells that produce antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen are selectively favored and survive, while those with lower affinity may undergo apoptosis.

choices.text: There is a positive correlation between pulse oximeter readings with and without micropore.
There is a negative correlation between pulse oximeter readings with and without micropore.
There is no correlation between pulse oximeter readings with and without micropore.
The available data is insufficient to draw any conclusions.

questions.text: A study examined the impact of using micropore on pulse oximeter readings in neonates. The collected data was visually represented on a graph. Based on this graph, which of the following conclusions is most accurate? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. There is a positive correlation between pulse oximeter readings with and without micropore.

 

Explanation:

 

A positive correlation signifies that as one variable changes, the other tends to change in the same direction. In the context of this study, if the pulse oximeter readings increase in neonates without micropore, we would expect them to similarly increase in neonates with micropore, and vice-versa. The reference text highlights that "Bland-Altman plots suggest that there is no significant loss of accuracy when readings are taken through the protective covering." This strongly suggests a consistent relationship between the readings obtained with and without micropore, implying a positive correlation.  

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. There is a negative correlation between the two groups: This would indicate an inverse relationship - as readings increase in one group, they decrease in the other. This contradicts the study's findings.
  • Option C. There is no correlation between the two groups: This suggests the absence of any relationship between the readings with and without micropore. The study's emphasis on accuracy with micropore use refutes this option.
  • Option D. The data is insufficient to comment: The question explicitly requests a conclusion based on the visual representation (the graph). As the graph depicts a relationship, this choice is not valid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive correlation implies that two variables tend to change in the same direction.
  • The study demonstrates a positive correlation between pulse oximeter readings with and without micropore, signifying that micropore doesn't significantly impact the accuracy of these readings in neonates.

choices.text: 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in smokers if smoking is eliminated
10% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

questions.text: A 45-year-old researcher is keenly interested in understanding the relationship between lung cancer and smoking habits. After conducting an extensive study and analyzing his data, he finds that the attributable risk is 90%. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of this result? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

 

  • In the given scenario, the attributable risk of cigarette smoking to lung cancer is 90%; hence, 90% cases of lung cancer are due to smoking as a risk factor
  • The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk.
  • Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure
  • Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding perimortem cesarean section? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper segment cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

An upper segment cesarean section is performed during a perimortem cesarean section (PMCS). PMCS is an emergency cesarean delivery of a woman who is expected to die within the next few moments or has just died.

 

Key points about PMCS:

 

  • Timing: According to the AHA 2020 Guidelines for CPR, perimortem cesarean should be considered if there is no return of spontaneous circulation within 5 minutes in a pregnant woman who has experienced total cardiopulmonary arrest.
  • Purpose: The goal of PMCS is to improve maternal and fetal outcomes by relieving the compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus, which enhances venous return and diaphragmatic displacement. This, in turn, improves respiratory dynamics and resuscitative efforts.
  • Fetal Outcome: The infant has a higher chance of survival if PMCS is performed within 10 minutes of maternal death.
  • Surgical Technique: A classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision is performed.
  • Location: PMCS does not need to be done in the operating theatre (OT); it can be done wherever the patient is located to expedite the process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LSCS: Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is not typically used in PMCS.

 

Option B. Pfannenstiel incision: This is a horizontal incision typically used in elective cesarean sections, not in emergency PMCS.

 

Option D. Done in OT: PMCS does not need to be performed in the operating theatre; it can be done immediately at the site of the patient to save time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perimortem cesarean section (PMCS) involves performing a classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision in an emergency situation to improve maternal and fetal outcomes.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459265/

choices.text: Mullerian agenesis
Gonadal dysgenesis
Turner syndrome
Testicular feminization syndrome

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl was brought by her mother to the outpatient department with primary amenorrhea. She had normal breast development and pubic hair. On examination, the vagina was blind-ending and the uterus was not palpable. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mullerian agenesis

 

  • The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea, normal breasts, and pubic hair, with a blind-ending vagina and uterus not palpable, is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis.
  • Absent uterus and vagina in a person with female genotype and phenotype are features of Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome.
  • As ovaries are present, normal secondary sexual characters will develop

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Gonadal dysgenesis: Gonadal dysgenesis patients present with primary amenorrhoea, absence of secondary sex characters poorly developed breasts

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: In Turner syndrome, short stature with poor development of secondary sexual characters and short stature will be seen. It has a karyotype of 45 XO. The ovaries are streak ovaries

 

Option D. Testicular feminization syndrome: Testicular feminization syndrome also known as androgen insensitivity syndrome has a karyotype of 46XY. Secondary sexual characters like the development of axillary hair and pubic hair are absent in these females. However, breast development is adequate due to the conversion of androgen into estrogen during puberty.

 

Educational Objective:


Mullerian agenesis is characterized by the absence of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina, with normal ovarian function leading to normal breast and pubic hair development.

 

Ref: Page no 450, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A study on postpartum depression in mothers compares depression rates based on the gender of their newborns using the Edinburgh Depression Scale Score (EDSS). Which statistical method should be used to determine if there's a significant association between the newborn's gender and postpartum depression? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Chi square test

 

  • The Chi-square test serves the purpose of comparing qualitative data and involves the comparison of two groups with independent measurements.
  • Therefore, it is the most suitable test for this context

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Students t test: Used for comparing means of two independent groups; not suitable for categorical data.

 

Option B. Paired t test: Used for comparing means of related groups; not suitable for independent categorical data.

 

Option C. ANOVA: Used for comparing means of three or more groups; not suitable for categorical data with only two groups.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 3-year-old child brought to the OPD with fever and a rash spreading from the face, behind cheeks, and buccal mucosa to other body parts. On examination, Koplik's spot is present. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Measles/Rubeola

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: The rash of rubella is similar in distribution to that of measles (rubeola) but it is less intensely red and confluent. Forchheimer spots (Red spots over palate) may be present.

 

 

Option C. Varicella: Varicella presents with rash which appears 24-48 hrs after prodromal symptoms, then rapidly to face & trunk. There are papules, vesicles & crusted vesicles, Centripetal distribution with greatest on trunk.

 

 

Option D. Mumps: Mumps presents with Painful enlargement of salivary gland, ear ache, jaw tenderness while chewing, dryness of mouth.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Koplik spots and a characteristic rash that begins on the forehead behind the ears and spreads to the torso and extremities are pathognomonic for measles.

questions.text: A patient with alkaline urine has the presence of the following type of urinary crystals. What is the likely composition of these crystals?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnesium ammonium phosphate

 

The presence of urinary crystals can help diagnose the type of stones a patient may be forming. The type of crystal seen in the urine is highly dependent on the urine pH:

 

Magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite): These crystals are typically found in alkaline urine and have a characteristic "coffin lid" appearance. They are associated with infections by urease-producing bacteria and are also known as staghorn calculi due to their large, branching structure in the kidneys.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Calcium oxalate: These crystals are typically found in acidic to neutral urine and have an envelope or dumbbell shape. They are the most common type of kidney stones.

 

Option B. Uric acid: These crystals are found in acidic urine and often have a rosette or irregular shape.

 

Option C. Cystine: These crystals appear in acidic urine and have a hexagonal shape, associated with cystinuria, a genetic disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Magnesium ammonium phosphate crystals, which appear as "coffin lid" shapes, are typically found in alkaline urine and are associated with struvite stones.

 

Urinary Crystals and pH Association:

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with severe dyspnea. Mitral stenosis with left atrial hypertrophy is seen. Vegetations present on the mitral valve were excised. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given HE image? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatic valvular disease

 

The given image depicts Aschoff's body, which is suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease. During acute Rheumatic Fever (RF), focal inflammatory lesions are found in various tissues. Distinctive lesions occur in the heart, called Aschoff bodies, which consist of foci of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF). These macrophages have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to ovoid nuclei in which the chromatin is disposed in a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation “caterpillar cells”) and may become multinucleated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infective endocarditis: Infective endocarditis is characterized by large, friable vegetations composed of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms, which would not exhibit the Aschoff bodies seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Myxoma: Myxomas are benign tumors of the heart that typically present as a gelatinous mass, and they do not feature Aschoff bodies or the inflammatory response seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that can affect the heart but does not produce the Aschoff bodies characteristic of rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Aschoff bodies, characterized by foci of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and Anitschkow cells, is pathognomonic for rheumatic valvular disease and indicates a history of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page no – 1044

questions.text: A 24-year-old lactating female with an 18-month-old child comes with a history of irregular, heavy bleeding seeking contraceptive advice. Which is the contraceptive of choice? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) levonorgesterel IUD

 

Explanation:

 

  • Suitable during lactation
    • LNG-IUS is a progestin-only method
    • Does not reduce milk production (unlike estrogen-containing pills)
  • Controls heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia)
    • LNG-IUS reduces menstrual blood loss by 70–90%
    • Improves hemoglobin levels and quality of life
  • Long-acting and reversible
    • Provides effective contraception for up to 5 years
    • Fertility returns quickly after removal
  • Low maintenance
    • No daily action required
    • Ideal for busy mothers with young children
  • High efficacy
    • Failure rate <0.2% per year
    • One of the most effective reversible methods
  • WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC)
    • Category 1 (no restriction) after 6 weeks postpartum
    • Safe for breastfeeding women
  • Fewer systemic side effects
    • Hormone acts locally in the uterus
    • Minimal systemic absorption

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Copper-T 380A: Copper-T 380A is a non-hormonal intrauterine device that may exacerbate heavy menstrual bleeding and would not be suitable for a patient already experiencing heavy bleeding.

 

Option C. Mala N: Mala N is also a possible contraceptive in this situation. There is high chance of non compliance and missed pill. LNG IUS is better option in such cases

 

Option D. Norethisterone enanthate - depot injection: Norethisterone enanthate is a progesterone-only injectable contraceptive. it may lead to delay in return to menses, and also requires follow up every 3 months for next dose, which is inconvenient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a lactating woman with a history of irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding, a combined oral contraceptive pill (COC) like Mala N is the preferred choice after the first 6 months postpartum as it helps regulate menstrual cycles and reduce menstrual flow.

 

Ref: Page no 398, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

questions.text: A young boy recently visited a temple with his grandmother. Upon returning, he has been crying inconsolably, presenting with cold extremities and a blood pressure of 170/100 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate course of treatment for his condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prazosin

 

The patient's symptoms are suggestive of scorpion sting, characterized by symptoms of vasoconstriction like hypertension and cold extremities. Prazosin, an alpha-1 blocker is drug of choice for treatment of scorpion sting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prednisolone: Prednisolone is a corticosteroid that reduces inflammation and suppresses the immune response. However, it is not typically used to manage scorpion stings, as it does not address the acute hypertensive crisis and autonomic storm caused by the sting.

 

Option C. Adrenaline: Adrenaline (epinephrine) is a catecholamine that increases heart rate and blood pressure. It would likely exacerbate the hypertension and vasoconstriction already present in the patient, making it an inappropriate treatment choice for scorpion sting.

 

Option D. Anti-snake venom: Anti-snake venom is used to neutralize the effects of snake bites. The symptoms described do not align with a snake bite but rather with a scorpion sting, making this treatment inappropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate treatment for a scorpion sting, which presents with severe pain, hypertension, and cold extremities, is prazosin. It effectively counters the effects of excessive catecholamine release by blocking alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, thereby reducing vasoconstriction and lowering blood pressure.

questions.text: The following image indicates: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oculomotor palsy

 

The given image suggests oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

The central image shows the eyes in primary gaze where the patient's left eye has deviated down and out. There is also ptosis of the left eyelid. From the eye movements, it can be seen that adduction, elevation, and depression are absent in the left eye.

 

All of these findings indicate oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Signs observed in a patient with oculomotor nerve palsy include:

 

  • Profound ptosis: This is due to the weakness of the levator muscle.
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out"): This is due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest: This is due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Limited adduction: This is due to medial rectus weakness.
  • Limited elevation: This is due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
  • Limited depression: This is due to the weakness of the inferior rectus.
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation: This is due to parasympathetic palsy.
  • Normal abduction: This is due to the intact lateral rectus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trochlear nerve palsy: Primarily affects the superior oblique muscle, leading to vertical diplopia and head tilt but does not cause ptosis or pupil involvement.

 

Option B. Lateral rectus palsy: Would lead to medial deviation of the eye due to unopposed action of the medial rectus muscle, affecting horizontal eye movement.

 

Option C. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia: Characterized by impairment of horizontal eye movements, particularly affecting the adduction of the eye on the side of the lesion, with nystagmus in the abducting eye, typically not involving the eyelid or pupil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculomotor palsy involves multiple dysfunctions including ptosis, "down and out" eye position, and possibly a dilated pupil. Recognizing the full range of symptoms is critical for a correct diagnosis, indicating a comprehensive evaluation of cranial nerve III integrity.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a rash after a trip. You observe a vector on his skin. Considering common vector-borne diseases, what is the disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image. ([INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Scrub typhus

 

Explanation:

 

The image provided shows a trombiculid mite, which is commonly involved in the transmission of Scrub Typhus.

 

  • Scrub Typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi and is primarily transmitted through bites of infected chiggers. The disease is prevalent in the Asia-Pacific region, so exposure in those areas following a rash and the sighting of a trombiculid mite on the skin strongly points to Scrub Typhus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Babesiosis: This is transmitted by Ixodes ticks (deer ticks), affecting red blood cells similar to malaria. It is not related to trombiculid mites.

 

Option B. Anaplasmosis: Transmitted by deer ticks and the western black-legged tick, this disease targets white blood cells. It's also not transmitted by trombiculid mites.

 

Option D. Ehrlichiosis: This disease is transmitted by ticks like the lone star tick and affects white blood cells. It does not involve trombiculid mites.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Scrub Typhus is transmitted by trombiculid mites, specifically the chigger larvae. It is characterized by fever, rash, and a black eschar at the site of the mite bite.

 

DOC – Doxycycline (monotherapy)

 

If severe manifestations – Doxycycline + Azithromycin

questions.text: What is the dose of Ulipristal used in emergency contraception? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30 mg

 

Explanation:

 

The dose of Ulipristal in emergency contraception is 30 mg to be taken within 72 hrs (can be taken upto 120hrs).

 

The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dose of Ulipristal for emergency contraception is 30 mg, to be taken within 72 hours (up to 120 hours) after unprotected intercourse.

 

Ref: Page no 630, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient underwent hernia surgery and complained of a loss of sensations over the root of his penis during his postoperative recovery. The patient reported no prior history of genital trauma or surgery. Which of the following nerves would you suspect to be the cause of the patient's loss of sensation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ilioinguinal nerve

 

The ilioinguinal nerve is the most likely nerve to be implicated in this scenario. It provides sensation to the skin over the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum, and can be injured during inguinal hernia repair surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Iliohypogastric nerve: The Iliohypogastric nerve carries sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve rarely causes sensory disturbances in the right iliac fossa due to the rich nerve supply from other sources. However, severing this nerve above the anterior superior iliac spine can lead to weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal, resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. Injury to this nerve can also occur following appendicectomy.

 

Option C. The genitofemoral nerve: The genitofemoral nerve has a genital branch that provides sensation to the scrotum in males and mons pubis and labia majora in females. Injury to the genital branch can cause loss of sensation in these areas.

 

The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament, but this is not relevant to the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh: The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh a sensory branch of the femoral nerve that supplies sensation to the anterior-medial aspect of the thigh and knee. Injury to this nerve can lead to loss of sensation in these areas, but is not related to the patient's loss of sensation in the root of the penis.

questions.text: During your residency, you learn about a specific protocol essential for physicians when dealing with challenging scenarios. This protocol, known as the SPIKES protocol, serves a unique purpose in medical communication. Can you identify the primary objective of employing the SPIKES protocol? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Breaking bad news

 

SPIKES PROTOCOL

 

  • Communication of cancer Diagnosis & Prognosis (or any adverse outcome)
  • Protocol of 6 steps

S - Set up interview

P - Perceptions

I - Invitation to explain

K - Knowledge

E - Emotions

S - Summary & Strategy

 

Best used for Communication of diagnosis and prognosis for Breast Cancer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triage: Incorrect. Triage involves prioritizing patient care based on the severity of their condition.

 

Option B. Consent for study participation: Incorrect. Obtaining consent for study participation requires a different communication protocol focused on informed consent.

 

Option C. Hospital infection control: Incorrect. Infection control involves protocols for preventing and managing infections within the hospital setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The SPIKES protocol is specifically designed to guide physicians in breaking bad news to patients, ensuring the communication is handled with sensitivity and clarity.

choices.text: Inhibits HMG Co reductase
Activates PPAR alpha
Binds to deoxycholic acid
Inhibit intestinal absorption of cholesterol

questions.text: A patient who is on treatment for hyperlipidemia develops gallstones. What is the mechanism of action of the causative drug that was given to this patient? ((INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Activates PPAR alpha

 

Fibrates, such as clofibrate, fenofibrate, and gemfibrozil, are used to treat hyperlipidemia. These drugs work by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARα). The activation of PPARα leads to:

 

  1. Increased synthesis of lipoprotein lipase, which accelerates the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins.
  2. Reduced production of VLDL and chylomicrons.
  3. Lower levels of triglycerides.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Statins inhibit HMG CoA reductase. These drugs are used as lipid-lowering agents in dyslipidemia and are associated with statin-induced myopathy. These drugs do not lead to development of gallstones.

 

Option C. Bile Acid Sequestrants bind to deoxycholic acid and prevent its reabsorption in the intestine. It may result in deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins.

 

Option D. Ezetimibe is a drug that acts by inhibiting intestinal absorption of cholesterol

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrates are lipid-lowering agents that work by activating PPARα. While effective at reducing triglycerides and VLDL, they can increase the risk of gallstone formation due to increased cholesterol content in bile. This is an important consideration when choosing lipid-lowering therapy, especially in patients at risk for cholelithiasis.

questions.text: A patient was treated with repeated doses of IV anti-emetic for severe vomiting. The patient now does not have vomiting but developed abnormal movements. What is the most appropriate treatment? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Benzhexol

 

The patient likely received intravenous metoclopramide, a common anti-emetic, which can cause extrapyramidal side effects such as dystonia. Dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary muscle contractions, leading to repetitive movements or abnormal postures. This condition can be painful and distressing.

 

The treatment of choice for drug-induced dystonia is an anticholinergic medication. Benzhexol (also known as trihexyphenidyl) is an anticholinergic drug that can effectively relieve dystonic reactions by blocking acetylcholine receptors in the central nervous system, thereby restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyoscine: Hyoscine (scopolamine) is primarily used to treat motion sickness and postoperative nausea. It is not effective for treating dystonia induced by anti-emetic medications.

 

Option C. Levodopa: Levodopa is used to treat Parkinson's disease by increasing dopamine levels in the brain. It is not appropriate for treating acute dystonic reactions caused by anti-emetic medications.

 

Option D. Cyproheptadine: Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with antiserotonergic and anticholinergic properties. While it can be used for some dystonic reactions, it is not the first-line treatment in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients who develop dystonic reactions after receiving anti-emetic medications like metoclopramide, the most appropriate treatment is an anticholinergic drug such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl). This helps alleviate the abnormal movements by restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the central nervous system.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti Hbc Ab

 

The Anti-HBc antibody (C) is the marker that will always be present in a patient's serum if they have been exposed to Hepatitis B virus (HBV). This marker is indicative of both past and ongoing infection and remains detectable for life. It indicates a previous or ongoing infection with HBV and is present in both acute and chronic stages of the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HBc Ag: Hepatitis B core antigen is typically not detectable in the serum. It is found within the hepatocyte and not usually present in the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Anti HBs Ab: The antibody against the Hepatitis B surface antigen indicates immunity to HBV, either from past infection or vaccination. It is not present during chronic infection without recovery.

 

Option D. HBe Ag: Hepatitis B e antigen is a marker of active viral replication and high infectivity. It is not present in all stages of infection, especially in chronic carriers where the virus may not be actively replicating.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to episodes of severe crying. The parents report that their child was playing normally but suddenly began screaming in pain, pulling his legs up to his abdomen, and having episodes of vomiting. The pain seemed to come and go every 10 to 15 minutes. This morning, they noticed his stool was red and mucous-like, resembling "currant jelly." On physical examination, the infant appears lethargic between episodes of pain, and a palpable mass is noted in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. The parents mention that he recently received his routine immunizations two weeks ago. Considering this presentation and the recent immunization, which recent vaccine is most commonly associated with an increased risk of intussusception in infants?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Rotavirus Vaccine

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of severe intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, and currant jelly stools in an infant is highly suggestive of intussusception, a common cause of bowel obstruction in young children. The Rotavirus vaccine, a live attenuated oral vaccine, is known to slightly increase the risk of intussusception, particularly within the first week after the initial doses. This risk, although slightly elevated, does not outweigh the vaccine's benefits in preventing severe rotavirus gastroenteritis, which can lead to significant dehydration, hospitalization, and even death in infants. This association necessitates vigilance for symptoms of intussusception following vaccination, particularly when parents report abdominal symptoms after the vaccine.

 

Rotavirus vaccines:

 

 

There are 4 types of Rotavirus vaccines, but only 2 are used in the National Immunization Schedule (NIS).

 

ROTAVAC and ROTASIIL are the commonly used vaccines; both are live attenuated vaccines, lyophilized with a diluent citrate bicarbonate buffer.

 

ROTAVAC: Administered in a dose of 0.5 ml per dose.

 

ROTASIIL: Administered in a dose of 2.5 ml with a 6 ml syringe.

 

The vaccination schedule includes 3 doses given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age.

 

A known complication of these vaccines is intussusception, which requires careful monitoring after administration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Influenza Vaccine
The Influenza vaccine is administered annually to prevent influenza infections and is not associated with intussusception. It is typically given as an injection and does not impact the gastrointestinal tract in a manner that would lead to intussusception.

 

Option C. Varicella Vaccine
The Varicella vaccine is given to prevent chickenpox, typically in older infants or children. It is not known to have any association with gastrointestinal conditions such as intussusception.

 

Option D. Polio Vaccine
The Polio vaccine, given orally or as an injection depending on the formulation, aims to protect against poliomyelitis. It is not associated with the risk of intussusception or other significant gastrointestinal complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a slight increase in the risk of intussusception, particularly following the initial doses in infancy. Healthcare providers should consider this when evaluating gastrointestinal symptoms in recently vaccinated infants, as early detection and management of intussusception can prevent serious complications. Familiarity with the types of Rotavirus vaccines and their schedules is essential in clinical practice to provide appropriate anticipatory guidance to parents.

choices.text: Incontinence when patient lies down and coughs

questions.text: A 37-year-old male comes with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS). Which of the following is not a typical presenting LUTS? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incontinence during intercourse

 

While urinary incontinence during intercourse can occur, it is not considered a typical lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS). LUTS typically encompasses symptoms related to storage and voiding of urine. Incontinence during intercourse might be related to other causes, including psychological factors, or specific conditions impacting the pelvic floor, but it's not a routine symptom when discussing LUTS.

 

Incontinence during sexual activity is not considered a lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sudden urge to urinate: This symptom is known as urgency and is a common lower urinary tract symptom. It is the sudden and strong desire to urinate, which can be difficult to delay.

 

Option B. Incontinence while asleep: This is referred to as nocturnal enuresis or bedwetting. It is a type of urinary incontinence where the patient involuntarily releases urine during sleep. This can be a symptom associated with a variety of conditions, including bladder issues, sleep disorders, or even psychological factors.

 

Option C. Incontinence when a patient lies down and coughs: This is known as stress incontinence. It occurs when physical movement or activity, such as coughing, sneezing, running, or heavy lifting, puts pressure (stress) on the bladder, causing unintentional urine leakage. It's often due to weakened pelvic floor muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LUTS can be divided into three categories: storage, voiding, and post-micturitional.

 

Storage LUTS involves the failure of the bladder to act as a urine reservoir, leading to symptoms such as increased frequency of voiding, nocturia, urgency, and urge incontinence.

 

Voiding LUTS is commonly seen in bladder outlet obstruction and includes symptoms such as hesitancy, reduced stream, and straining.

 

Post-micturitional LUTS, also caused by bladder outlet obstruction, includes symptoms such as incomplete emptying and post-micturition dribble. Other symptoms of LUTS include stress incontinence, nocturnal enuresis, and strangury.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs exacerbates myasthenia and is usually avoided in a patient with myasthenia gravis? (INICET Nov 2020)

1. Lidocaine

2. Aspirin

3. Meropenem

4. Phenytoin
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1 and 4
 

1. Lidocaine can exacerbate myasthenia gravis and should be used with caution in patients with this disease. Lidocaine can cause neuromuscular blockade, which can worsen the muscle weakness and fatigue associated with myasthenia gravis.

 

4. Phenytoin is an antiepileptic drug that can cause neuromuscular blockade, which can exacerbate the muscle weakness and fatigue associated with myasthenia gravis. Therefore, it is generally avoided in patients with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Aspirin

 

  • Mechanism: Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory and antiplatelet drug. It does not have neuromuscular blocking properties and does not exacerbate myasthenia gravis.
  • Use in Myasthenia Gravis: Aspirin is generally safe for use in myasthenia gravis patients.

 

3. Meropenem

 

  • Mechanism: Meropenem is a broad-spectrum antibiotic. While some antibiotics can interfere with neuromuscular transmission, meropenem is not typically associated with exacerbating myasthenia gravis.
  • Use in Myasthenia Gravis: Meropenem is usually considered safe for use in myasthenia gravis patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DRUGS THAT SHOULD BE AVOIDED IN MYSTHENIA GRAVIS

questions.text: Identify the clinical sign shown in the image below:(NEET  PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Popeye sign

 

The above image depicts the popeye sign, which is caused by a rupture of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii.

 

Popeye sign:

 

  • Description: This refers to the prominent bulge of the biceps muscle in the arm.
  • Cause: The sign is named after the cartoon character "Popeye the Sailor Man" who had bulging forearm muscles. It's observed in cases where there's a rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon. When the tendon ruptures, the muscle can sometimes ball up, creating a bulge in the mid-arm.
  • Clinical Relevance: Often accompanied by pain and weakness, it usually requires clinical evaluation to determine the need for surgical intervention.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs sign (or lesion):

 

  • Description: It is a compression fracture of the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head.
  • Cause: This lesion occurs when the humeral head impacts against the anterior glenoid rim during an anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • Clinical Relevance: The presence of a Hill-Sachs lesion can predispose an individual to recurrent shoulder dislocations. Its size and location may dictate treatment strategy in recurrent shoulder instability.

 

 

Option C. Griesinger sign:

 

  • Description: It refers to the presence of a postauricular sulcus or groove behind the ear.
  • Cause: This sign is seen in cases of acute mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media. The groove results from the edema and venous congestion in the sigmoid sinus secondary to the adjacent inflammation.
  • Clinical Relevance: Acute mastoiditis is a serious condition that requires prompt treatment, often including surgical intervention. The presence of Griesinger's sign helps in clinical diagnosis.

 

Option D. Rising sun sign:

 

  • Description: This is a radiological sign observed on imaging of the head.
  • Cause: It's seen in cases of tuberous sclerosis, a genetic disorder. On imaging, it refers to the appearance of subependymal nodules in the lateral ventricles that project into the ventricle. The nodules resemble the sun rising over the horizon.
  • Clinical Relevance: Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by the growth of benign tumors in many parts of the body. The presence of the "Rising sun" sign can help confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Popeye sign is a clinical indication of the rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon, leading to a characteristic bulging of the biceps muscle, which requires thorough clinical assessment and possibly surgical repair.

choices.text: Use MR vaccine and discard pentavalent vaccine
Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

questions.text: An auxiliary nurse midwife is tasked with organizing a vaccination camp within a rural community. She has been provided with 2 vials that have been unsealed. Among these, one contains a pentavalent vaccine, while the other holds an MR vaccine. What options does she have in terms of effectively using these vials? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

 

According to the Open Vial Policy, certain vaccines can be used for subsequent sessions for up to 4 weeks after opening, provided they have been stored properly and are not expired. This policy helps to minimize vaccine wastage and ensure efficient use of available vaccines.

 

Open Vial Policy (2015)

 

  • Opened vaccine vials can be used in subsequent session ‘UPTO 4 WEEKS’
  • Open vial policy – 
    • Applicable for - Hep B, OPV, DPT, Liquid pentavalent, TT, PCV, IPV, HiB
    • Not applicable for - BCG, MR, JE, RVV, Covid-19 vaccines
  • Expiry date should not pass, VVM within usability limits, Cold chain maintenance
  • Vaccine vial septum not submerged in water or contaminated, Aseptic technique used to withdraw doses
  • Record date and time of each vial opening
  • At end of session return all open vials to Cold chain:
    • Reusable open vials: DPT, DT, Hepatitis B, Pentavalent
    • Non-reusable open vials: Measles, BCG, JE (Destroy after 48 hours or Next session whichever earlier)
    • If any AEFI reported: Store all vials in Cold chain till completion of investigation

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Under the Open Vial Policy, the auxiliary nurse midwife can use the pentavalent vaccine for subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks after opening, but must discard the MR vaccine as it does not fall under the Open Vial Policy.

questions.text: A triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex and eosinophilia is seen in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EGPA

 

Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA), formerly known as Churg-Strauss Syndrome, is characterized by a combination of asthma, eosinophilia, and vasculitis affecting multiple organ systems.

 

The clinical triad of skin lesions (such as purpura or nodules), asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex (manifesting as numbness, pain, or muscle weakness typically in the limbs), and eosinophilia is highly suggestive of this condition. EGPA is a type of ANCA-associated vasculitis but differs from others in its prominent eosinophilic involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis: Typically associated with hepatitis C infection and features immune complexes in the blood that precipitate in the cold. It commonly presents with palpable purpura, joint pains, and kidney involvement but not typically with eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN): A medium vessel vasculitis that may present with similar features including neuropathy and skin lesions but does not typically include eosinophilia as a prominent feature.

 

Option D. Giant cell arteritis (GCA): Primarily affects large vessels, particularly the temporal arteries, and presents with symptoms such as headache, jaw claudication, and potential blindness. It does not feature the triad of skin lesions, mononeuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EGPA is a distinctive form of vasculitis marked by asthma, eosinophilia, and a systemic vasculitis involving skin and nerves among other systems. Its recognition is crucial due to the need for early and aggressive treatment to prevent significant morbidity and mortality.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Vasculitis/Chap 363

choices.text: 6 follicular clusters each with 10 cells each
3 follicular clusters with 10-15 cells each
10 follicular cell clusters with 6-8 cells each
12 follicular cell clusters with 10-12 cells each

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presented with a thyroid nodule that was detected on routine physical examination. The patient underwent a fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) procedure to determine the nature of the nodule. The results of the FNAC were inconclusive, and the patient was advised to undergo a repeat FNAC. The patient is now confused about the correct technique for obtaining an adequate thyroid FNAC sample. As a healthcare professional, which of the following would you explain to the patient regarding adequate thyroid FNAC sampling? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6 follicular clusters each with 10 cells each

 

Adequate sampling during thyroid fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is crucial for accurate diagnosis. The criterion of having six follicular clusters with at least 10 cells in each cluster is considered adequate for a conclusive evaluation. This ensures that there is enough cellular material to assess the architectural and cytological features necessary for an accurate diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 3 follicular clusters with 10-15 cells each - This option may not provide a sufficient number of cells or clusters to make a definitive diagnosis, leading to potentially inconclusive results.

 

Option C. 10 follicular cell clusters with 6-8 cells each - Although this provides a higher number of clusters, the lower number of cells per cluster might not meet the minimum requirements for adequate assessment.

 

Option D. 12 follicular cell clusters with 10-12 cells each - While this would typically provide ample cells, it is not the standard criterion referenced in guidelines for FNAC adequacy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that for thyroid FNAC, having six follicular clusters with at least 10 cells in each is considered adequate for a thorough and conclusive diagnostic evaluation.

choices.text: Aspirin increases fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
PGI2 is responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level
Fever occurs during inflammation due to release of histamine

questions.text: Which of the following is true about fever? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IL-1 is an endogenous pyrogen

 

Fever is a common symptom of many illnesses, and it is an important defense mechanism of the body. It is often associated with infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Pyrogens are substances that cause fever.

 

IL-1 (interleukin-1) is an endogenous pyrogen, meaning that it is a substance produced by the body that induces fever. It is produced by activated immune cells such as macrophages and monocytes in response to infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. IL-1 acts on the hypothalamus to increase the set point of the thermostat, leading to a higher body temperature.

 

  • Endogenous pyrogens, such as prostaglandins, IL-1, and TNF
  • Exogenous pyrogens, which are bacterial lipopolysaccharides. They cause endogenous pyrogens to be released from leukocytes (IL-1 and TNF)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) actually reduce fever by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins, which are involved in the process of fever. Prostaglandins are produced by cells in the hypothalamus in response to pyrogens (fever-inducing substances), and they increase the set point of the hypothalamic thermostat, leading to a higher body temperature. NSAIDs inhibit the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is required for the synthesis of prostaglandins, thereby reducing fever.

 

Option B. PGI2 (prostaglandin I2): PGI2 (prostaglandin I2) is not responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level.

 

Option D. Histamine: Histamine is not directly involved in the process of fever, although it is involved in the process of inflammation. Histamine is a chemical mediator that is released by mast cells and other immune cells in response to injury or infection, and it causes dilation of blood vessels and increased permeability of capillaries. This leads to the characteristic redness, swelling, and heat that are associated with inflammation. However, histamine does not directly cause fever.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis is not responding well to conventional treatment. Her rheumatologist is considering adding tocilizumab to her treatment regimen. Which of the following interleukins (IL) is primarily targeted by tocilizumab? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IL-6

 

  • Tocilizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets and inhibits the interleukin-6 (IL-6) receptor. By blocking the IL-6 receptor, tocilizumab interrupts the signaling pathway of IL-6, a cytokine involved in the inflammatory response. This is particularly beneficial in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, where elevated levels of IL-6 contribute to the inflammatory process.
  • Tocilizumab has also been used in COVID-19 for cytokine release syndrome.
  • It is avoided in patients with liver disease, immunosuppression, having a high risk of GIT perforation, Absolute Neutrophil Count <500 cell/µl and Platelet count <50000 cells/µl.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IL-2: Drugs like basiliximab or daclizumab are used to target IL-2 receptors.

 

Option C. IL-4: Dupilumab is an example of a medication that targets IL-4.

 

Option D. IL-5: Mepolizumab and reslizumab are examples of medications that target IL-5.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tocilizumab targets the IL-6 receptor, making it effective for managing rheumatoid arthritis and certain other inflammatory conditions by inhibiting the IL-6 signaling pathway.

questions.text: Pegloticase is used in the treatment of (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chronic gout

 

Pegloticase is a recombinant form of uricase, an enzyme that converts uric acid into allantoin, a more water-soluble substance that is easily excreted by the kidneys. Humans naturally lack this enzyme, and pegloticase is specifically designed to address the accumulation of uric acid in patients with gout.

 

Pegloticase is particularly indicated for the treatment of chronic gout in patients who have not responded to conventional therapies. Due to its potential immunogenicity, which can lead to infusion reactions including anaphylaxis, pegloticase is reserved for rare cases of refractory symptomatic chronic gout.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paralytic ileus: Paralytic ileus is a condition of impaired bowel motility. Pegloticase has no role in the treatment of paralytic ileus.

 

Option C. Psoriatic arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. Treatments typically include NSAIDs, DMARDs, and biologics, but not pegloticase.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder treated with NSAIDs, corticosteroids, DMARDs, and biologic agents. Pegloticase is not used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Pegloticase is used in the treatment of chronic gout, particularly in patients who have not responded to other therapies, due to its ability to lower uric acid levels by converting it to allantoin.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 235

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigation is used for a definitive diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Globin gene sequencing

 

Based on the clinical presentation of low hemoglobin levels, the presence of target cells in the blood smear, and the need for repeated blood transfusions, the most likely diagnosis is thalassemia. Thalassemia is an inherited disorder affecting the production of alpha- or beta-globin chains, leading to an imbalance in globin chain synthesis. This imbalance results in ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis, requiring frequent blood transfusions.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thalassemia: A genetic disorder that can be categorized into alpha-thalassemia and beta-thalassemia based on the affected globin chain. The severity of the condition depends on the number of functioning globin genes.
  • Definitive Diagnosis: The definitive diagnosis of thalassemia is made through globin gene sequencing, which identifies mutations in the genes encoding the globin chains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC): HPLC is used as a screening tool for thalassemia and other hemoglobinopathies by analyzing hemoglobin fractions. However, it is not definitive for diagnosing thalassemia.

 

Option B. Ferritin levels estimation: Ferritin levels are used to assess iron stores in the body, particularly in cases of iron deficiency anemia or iron overload. It is not diagnostic for thalassemia.

 

Option C. Bone marrow aspiration: While bone marrow aspiration can reveal ineffective erythropoiesis and hypercellularity, it is not used for a definitive diagnosis of thalassemia.

 

Hemoglobin Patterns:

 

  • Normal Hemoglobin Pattern: HbA = 95%, HbA2 = 3.5%, HbF = 1.5%
  • Beta-thalassemia Trait: HbA = 90%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 5%
  • Beta-thalassemia Intermedia: HbA = 45%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 50%

 

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis is another tool used for screening, often complemented by HPLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Globin gene sequencing is the definitive test for diagnosing thalassemia, a genetic disorder affecting hemoglobin production.

questions.text: When considering a patient with lung cancer, the imaging studies have measured the tumor size at 2.5 cm. According to the TMN staging system, which stage would be appropriate for this patient? ( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T1c

 

T1c: Correct. T1c is for tumors > 2 to ≤ 3 cm in size, which matches the patient's tumor size of 2.5 cm.

 

According to TNM staging, a patient with lung carcinoma of size 2.5cm is staged as T1c.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T2b: Incorrect. T2b is used for tumors > 4 to ≤ 5 cm in size.

 

Option C. T2a: Incorrect. T2a is for tumors > 3 to ≤ 4 cm in size.

 

Option D. T1a: Incorrect. T1a is for tumors < 1 cm in size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The TNM staging system for lung cancer uses tumor size and extent (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M) to classify the disease. A tumor measuring 2.5 cm is classified as T1c according to the TNM 8th edition criteria.

choices.text: Red - Immediate, Yellow - Delayed, Green - Minor, Black - Expectant
Green - Immediate, Black - Minor, Red - Delayed, Yellow - Expectant
Yellow - Immediate, Red - Delayed, Black - Minor, Green - Expectant
Black - Immediate, Green - Delayed, Yellow - Minor, Red - Expectant

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman arrives at the emergency department following a multi-vehicle collision. She is conscious but has significant chest trauma and difficulty breathing. Meanwhile, a 25-year-old man with multiple open fractures but stable vitals arrives by ambulance. Several other patients, including a 60-year-old man with severe burns and no pulse, and a 40-year-old woman with minor abrasions, are also brought in. The medical team must quickly assess and prioritize care based on injury severity and available resources. Which of the following triage color codes correctly matches each patient's priority level for receiving medical attention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Red - Immediate, Yellow - Delayed, Green - Minor, Black – Expectant

 

Explanation:

 

Triage is a critical process used in emergency medicine to categorize patients based on the severity of their injuries and the urgency of their need for medical treatment. The four primary color codes used in triage are:

 

Red (High Priority): For patients needing immediate life-saving interventions, such as those with compromised airways, chest trauma, or shock, like the woman with chest trauma in this scenario.

 

Yellow (Moderate Priority): For patients with serious but not immediately life-threatening injuries, such as open fractures with stable vitals, like the 25-year-old man in this scenario.

Green (Low Priority/Ambulatory): For minor injuries or conditions, such as minor abrasions, that do not require urgent intervention, like the 40-year-old woman.

 

Black (Expectant/Deceased): For patients with little chance of survival or those already deceased, like the 60-year-old man with no pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Triage in emergency settings involves assigning color codes to patients based on the urgency of their medical needs. The Red code is for immediate intervention, Yellow is for delayed but urgent care, Green is for minor or non-urgent cases, and Black is for those who are expectant or deceased. Understanding triage protocols ensures effective prioritization and resource allocation during emergencies.

questions.text: Which item below does not qualify as personal protective equipment? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Lab coat

 

A lab coat is not a personal protective equipment.

 

While lab coats are worn in laboratory settings to protect clothing and skin from spills and splashes, they are not classified as PPE. PPE refers to more specialized equipment designed to provide a barrier against specific hazards.

 

Other 3 options are considered as PPE

 

Educational Objective:

 

Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) are:

 

  • Gloves - protect hands.
  • Gowns/ aprons - protect skin and clothing.
  • Masks protect the mouth/nose and respirators protect the respiratory tract from airborne infectious agents.
  • Goggles - protect eyes.
  • Face shields - protect face, mouth, nose, and eyes.

questions.text: A ten-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and swelling of hands after playing football. He gives a history of previous episodes of swelling of hands. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sickle cell anemia

 

History is suggestive of dactylitis precipitated by playing causing microvascular obstruction. Shrunken spleen suggestive of auto splenectomy with recurrent episodes of dactylitis suggests sickle cell anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria: Typically presents with cyclical fever, chills, and splenomegaly rather than a shrunken spleen. The history of recurrent hand swelling isn't typical for malaria.

 

Option C. Pancreatitis: Main symptoms include severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, unrelated to the symptoms described in the case.

 

Option D. Measles: Characterized by a rash, fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots, none of which relate to the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

In a child presenting with fever and recurrent hand swelling following physical activity, alongside a history of a shrunken spleen, sickle cell anemia should be considered a primary diagnosis. This highlights the importance of considering hemoglobinopathies in patients with peculiar skeletal pains and organ findings suggestive of chronic hemolytic processes.

 

Reference - Harrison 21 /Hemoglobinopathies/Chapter 98

questions.text: Which gene defect causes familial hyperlipidemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDLr

 

Familial hyperlipidemia, particularly familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), is a genetic disorder characterized by high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. The primary cause of this condition is mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene.

 

Mechanism of Action: The LDL receptor is responsible for the uptake of LDL cholesterol from the blood into the liver. When there are mutations in the LDLr gene, the receptors are either dysfunctional or deficient. As a result, LDL cholesterol cannot be effectively removed from the bloodstream, leading to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol. This condition significantly increases the risk of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular diseases.

 

  • Heterozygous FH: This form is more common and results in moderately high LDL cholesterol levels (200-300 mg/dL). It is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases.
  • Homozygous FH: This form is rarer and more severe, with LDL cholesterol levels potentially reaching 600-700 mg/dL. Individuals with homozygous FH have a very high risk of early cardiovascular events and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ApoE:  Mutations in the ApoE gene cause familial dysbetalipoproteinemia (Type III hyperlipoproteinemia in Frederickson classification), which leads to elevated levels of intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDL) and is characterized by the presence of remnant particles in the blood.

 

Option B. ApoCII:  Deficiency in ApoCII causes familial chylomicronemia syndrome (Type I hyperlipoproteinemia in Frederickson classification). This condition is associated with extremely high levels of triglycerides due to impaired lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activation, which is necessary for the breakdown of triglycerides.

 

Option D. ApoB48:  ApoB48 is involved in the assembly and secretion of chylomicrons from the intestine. There is no known condition caused by a deficiency of ApoB48 that leads to familial hyperlipidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene cause familial hypercholesterolemia, a condition characterized by high levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood due to impaired clearance by the liver. This condition significantly increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases.

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling, compressing the trachea and esophagus. Histopathological assessment shows cell nests and pink extracellular amyloid stroma. What is the cell of origin of this tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parafollicular C cells

 

The presence of amyloid stroma in the context of a thyroid tumor is indicative of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland. These cells are responsible for secreting calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis. The amyloid stroma seen in MTC is due to the deposition of calcitonin-derived polypeptides.

 

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): This is a unique type of thyroid cancer that originates from parafollicular C cells. The hallmark of MTC is the presence of amyloid stroma, which results from calcitonin secretion by these cells.

 

Note -

 

  • The tumor marker for Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC) and Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (FTC) is thyroglobulin.
  • The tumor marker for Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) is calcitonin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Askanazy cells: These cells, also known as Hurthle cells, are large eosinophilic cells found in the thyroid gland but are typically associated with Hurthle cell carcinoma, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option C. Hurthle cells: These cells are a variant of follicular cells and are characteristic of Hurthle cell carcinoma. They do not produce amyloid stroma.

 

Option D. Follicular cells: These cells give rise to other types of thyroid cancers, such as papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) and follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC). These tumors do not typically feature amyloid stroma and are more commonly associated with thyroglobulin as a tumor marker, not calcitonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is characterized by amyloid stroma and originates from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland.
